column3: Will the service be better?

How can we get more people to take public transportation?

As a renter, what's the point in imagining how to improve transportation in my neighborhood if I won't be able to afford to live there when the improvements are complete? Affordable housing must be a part of this conversation.

what would it take for Boston to be the safest place in the US for kids to bike to school?

Can we reduce jaywalking and make it safer for pedestrians to cross large streets by having timed walk signals in more intersections? For example, in NYC there are no buttons to push- traffic signals also cycle through pedestrian walk signals.

Can we use drones to get around Boston?

Can the walk signals be longer?  (I'm in Valencia Spain and it seems as if there is more time to cross.  My partner has Parkinson's and it feels like we are always running across the street in Boston)
Will there be transportation infrastructure developed that doesn't rely on fossil fuels so that we can preserve our community and ensure that Boston achieves its climate goals?
Will Boston's public transportation networks be upgraded to be resilient to flooding and extreme storms?

What if there was no use for cars?
How about bus rapid transit?
How about bus rapid transit?
Can bicycles be welcome on ALL roads, not just designated lanes?
Will drivers yield with courtesy to pedestrians, bicycles and buses?

When can we expect traffic signals for bikes?
How can we ease friction between cars, bikes, and pedestrians?
Will rising demand make clearing paths for cyclists (a la the Southwest Corridor) in winter weather finally become a priority and not a pipe dream?

What if double- and triple-parking never happened?
What if people felt safe on our streets, even walking alone or late at night?
What if we stopped promoting the myth that cycling is inherently dangerous? What if we stopped pretending helmets are the answer?
What if you could rent a cargo bike, like you can a Zipcar?
What if you could request a pedicab from your phone?
What if we made it easy to make the sustainable choice?
If Forest Hills cannot have a new bridge, may we please have a Hovenring?

Can biking in Boston ever be safe enough that everyone - young and old - feels comfortable doing it?  I've biked in Boston since I was 10 or 11 (34 now) but there is a serious learning curve.  Is there bike infrastructure that would make it easier and safer for novice bicyclists, especially those who are not necessarily in great physical shape, to take advantage of the benefits of biking in the city?
How can we improve public transportation in the corridor between the Red and Orange Lines without accelerating gentrification?
Can I ride a bicycle from JP to Cambridge on a safe (separated from road) continuous bike path?
Can we convert some of our existing roadways to bikeways to separate the bikes from the cars?
Can we have free vans looping around neighborhood shopping districts?
How are old people who can no longer drive and can't walk to the bus stop or the subway station supposed to get around?

Why does Downtown Crossing, one of the most trafficked stations on the system, have to be a dilapidated shambles of a bunker? Shouldn't we put our best foot forward to visitors and make commuting more pleasant?
What if a 10 year old could safely ride their bike to any destination in the city? What if they and their parents didn't have to worry about a thoughtless driver changing all their lives forever?

Can a cross-walk see me coming with bags of groceries hanging from BOTH hands and give me a walk signal right-away instead of requiring me to put them down in the slush, or hold them all in one hand, or land on my tail by attempting to give the button a roundhouse kick?  Sometimes I will see the main street get TWO goes before I get mine --- IS THAT FAIR?
Why did they make the full adult cash bus fare on the worlds slowest fare box two dollars and *TEN* cents ($2.10)?
Will Needham please become willing to host the southern terminus of the Orange line?
Omnibuses were invented over one hundred and fifty years ago! --- Can any one control Bus Bunching yet?

Will every neighborhood have a circulator van like the Mission Hill Link or the discontinued #48 bus in JP that anyone (eg. the elderly, people carrying goods, parents with children in tow etc.) can use to get around the neighborhood, to the shops on "main-street" or connect to the "big-bus" or train?

What if roads were designed so that people actually went the speed limit?
How can we make biking safer on Mass Ave. between Cambridge and the Southwest Corridor?

How can we remove all the cars parked on bicycling lanes because of Juno?
How can we upgrade the trains so that they look nicer and run better (i.e. both doors open)?
When will the MBTA build a circular/ring line so that people don't have to always go to Park Street to transfer from one line to another?

When will the Orange Line stop feeling like the forgotten line?

When will the urban ring be completed? Now it is fine to get in and out of downtown, but difficult travel on public transportation around the ring. For example, there is no direct service from   JP to Newton; JP to Kenmore Sq. etc.

How will Boston make the streets more bike friendly and allow for bike commuters to feel safe and (lawfully) protected?  IE will there ever be police presence for the sole reason of protecting bicyclists?

When will the eta for trains be improved? I wait 10+ min for a "3min" train on the orange line. Why even have a clock countdown if it's not vaguely accurate?

Is it possible that Boston could create more zones reserved for pedestrians and cyclists? And more ways to discourage residents from driving everywhere?
How can we make biking in Boston so safe that almost anyone can do it, not just the people who are willing to risk their lives riding with car traffic?

Are there plans for a small hop on hop off bus for communities like JP, Rosie, that might loop onto Moss Hill where we have zero MBTA access today?

Can we do an express service on the #39 bus and other highly used bus lines such as the #1 and the #66?  Too many times, they make every stop and then catch up with one another - and it's 2 in a row!  Express stops could be every 4 stops or so.
How do we give higher priority to public transportation where congestion exists instead of trying to find space for more cars?
Will our sidewalks be passable to everyone--the growing elderly population, people with small kids, people with disabilities--after snowstorms both large and small?
What if public transportation were made cheaper and more convenient than private vehicles through tolls, tax incentives and investment in infrastructure?

Can we have drop-off/pick-up zones next to major stations so that cars will stop stalling in the middle of traffic to drop people off, or blocking off side streets and polluting them with car exhaust while waiting to pick people up? I'm thinking of Forest Hills station.
What kind of technological and creative advances are being held back right now because Jamaica Plain is so isolated from Cambridge and Somerville?

What if buses avoided 'stacking' by allowing people to consolidate into a single bus at the next stop, so that the stacked bus can wait a few minutes at that stop, and then the people who miss the stacked buses won't be stuck waiting 20 or 30 minutes for the next bus?
Can we please build a public transit system that works well?  One that uses a subway urban ring so that buses do not get stuck in traffic?
How can we make MBTA workers accountable for their poor communication and rudeness to customers?
What is your plan to improve snow removal?  One storm can currently cripple the roadways, the buses, and the trains.
What would it take to move the entire subway system underground from end to end for all lines, so that it can be more efficient?
With our narrow, twisty streets, is there any way to have cars and bikes co-exist safely and in harmony? I ride everywhere in the city now, but most people I know are too afraid to do so.
When a bus or train is "one hour delayed," what does it mean?  If every train is delayed one hour, after an hour passes they arrive on schedule.
Can we have some "car only" streets where there are nearby bike paths? Amory St in JP is an example. Some streets are too narrow to accommodate both safely.
#1 bus, CT 1 bus - similar but different routes with an odd name. What's it mean?
@GoBoston2030 How will the City guarantee that transportation development does not contribute to gentrification & displacement? #right2remain #Rmbta

What I want to know is when Boston is going to live up to it's moto as a "Walkable City", and work to promote, ensure and demand high standards of actually achieving Walkability ALL year round.  Connectivity between pedestrian and bicycle paths and sidewalks and transit are paramount to promoting transportation independence for those who do not exclusively rely on automobiles to get around (whether it be due to choice or physical, economical circumstance).   This connectivity is precisely what promotes the type of recreational, employment, commercial and residential density that Boston is celebrated for and/ or is committed to furthering.  However, during this week the rhetoric around snow has bee firstly, "well we just got to much snow to handle, sorry we cant manage it.  Which is then followed up with rhetoric that is consistently heavily weighed towards, "don't exhert yourself shoveling", "be careful driving on the streets".  And instead it should be a safety campaign that shows pedestrians walking in the street or children waiting in the street for a school bus with the emphatic statement of, "it's all our responsibility to keep our residents safe, shovel your sidewalks".  But instead, the city has loosely enforced policies that don't actually force property owners to make walkways, a public resource, safe to travel on.  I'll leave you with the point that transportation independence is a quality of life issue that impacts ability to travel to jobs, run errands, recreate, etc‰Û_  If you want to make Boston the World Class City that we like to promote ourselves as we would actually work to make travel by car feasible ALL year round.  Boston is not the vanguard of cities learning how to run municipal services during inclement weather.  Other cities with similar climate/ weather maintain connectivity even in the coldest/ snowiest of months.   By not holding residents to a high standard for keeping our sidewalks and multi use paths safe you are essentially sending the message that you don't actually take the safety of the elderly who may not be able to drive anymore, young people who don't have a license yet, the parents who has to travel with a stroller or small children, any individual who uses a mobility assistance device like a wheel chair, walker, cane, etc‰Û_ seriously.     And if we are to become the City that we imagine ourselves to be, Go Boston 2030 will need to address municipal service management and policies geared specifically towards snow removal management for ALL modes of transportation.  Otherwise, and this week has been a perfect case in point,  you risk alienating a large part of the population who choose to live here because of the density, has no control over their transportation choices, or whom can't afford other options.  How's that for equity?
Will the MBTA bring back the #48 Jamaica Plain loop bus that used to pass by 125 Amory Street?
How do I get to class if it snows 5 feet?
Will we have enhanced public transportation, including more boat transportation?

When will New England build true high-speed rail: 45 minutes Boston to Springfield, 90 minutes Boston to New York. This would open up western Mass. to having a real economic relationship with the Boston area.
When will the rapid transit routes through the city be expanded to carry the traffic of the future?

How can we better coordinate the MBTA and Boston Public Schools for transportation for our children?  Buses frequently are so overcrowded they don't stop for children (ages 12 +) trying to get to school, many times up to 7 buses in a row will not stop for a child.  This results in children late to school which results in detention that day for the child.  If the new BPS plan requires families to choose schools within one mile of their house will this free up school buses since less children will be entitled to transportation within that 1 mile radius.  Will that improve the school transportation for middle and high school students?

Need more parking at commuter rail stations.  Right now the commuter rail is not feasible for many because you need to get to the stations by 6:30am to get a parking spot.  These people end up driving into the city.  It would be a huge boost to commuters, the environment and traffic if these people could get on public transportation instead.

Transit-Oriented Development is one of the leading causes of gentrification displacement. How will the City of Boston guarantee that transportation funds will not contribute to displacement, and will benefit low-income people and transit-dependent riders? #right2remain #Rmbta

We all know that our subway/bus system is the oldest in the country.  When are we going to be able to truly depend on the T for reliable service?  I've been at the mercy of the bus and subway system for years (since 1977) and the #39 bus has been nonexistent for helping me.  The subway is fairly dependable.  The bus system leaves people waiting forever - and they post that it comes every 18 minutes!  I can't tell you how many times I've waited for the #39 bus - either at Back Bay station or on Centre Street in Jamaica Plain - for 20, 30 minutes or more and that's only one mile from Forest Hills!  Then 3 buses will pass you - after you've given up on them coming and you start walking and more of them stop to pick up people because they are so concerned with spreading out the service for the buses - the way they were supposed to be.  They are failing to provide predictable service for people who don't have a car, or are elderly.  There is not enough space for me to comment on how poorly the bus service has been here since 1977 - terrible.
Can we (Boston) raise funds to update transportation so it is better equipped for various weather conditions, i.e. snow?
What is the City planning to do with eco-friendly transportation in the near future?
Not a question- but a challenge... It took me 15 minutes (not rush hour) to drive to work... JP to Fenway. It takes about an hour on public transportation. So... I drive.
In the future, will bike lanes be physically separated from traffic?
Why are the same roads being fixed and not others?
Why are there not enough buses/trains during certain hours of the day, like 6 a.m.?  Why doesn't transportation begin earlier?  First shift?
How can the City ensure that all sidewalks are cleared after it snows?
What can we do to have the commuter rail run more often?
If trolley tracks are not being used, will they be taken out to increase safety, especially in the winter?
What if everyone biked?
